comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content:
The tower with the clock circle - but no hands, and indeed with no clock - adorns the Lands Department Building in Bridge Street. It remained without a clock until 1938. Closer view here (c1900) with interesting commentary from State Records NSW:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5401920179/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] Good work! I think this is slightly earlier than the c.1910 photo next door, due to the different signs on the Paragon Hotel (Christie's Umbrellas) - close inspection shows that the Paragon hasn't yet been extended west (c.1909 - see extensive research by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] here - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6031629514/ ). The additional two floors to the Customs House happened by 1902, so we are looking at 1902-09 so far - c.1905? At that time they were gradually replacing the old curved-roof Victorian ferry wharf buildings with mock-tudor (imho hideous) federation-style ones.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: ? is that a date 16-10-03 on the lower rh corner...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] It could well be - the shadows look about right for 3.15 pm on a mid-October afternoon (I don't really know!).  I have a feeling electric street lamps arrived in Circular Quay around 1904 too - not evident here,  but there is evidence of tram-wire poles.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] remember these wonderful SRNSW panorama pics which were taken from the Dawes Point chimney? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5353034008/] ...I think we more or less established they were taken in late 1903 or early 1904...though there were a few questions remaining re whether they were all taken on the one occasion, etc...pity there's not a tad more resolution...but I can't see the Christies sign in this SRNSW pic... Here's one of the 'missing' pics from the panorama which turned up in the T&CJ some months later in June 1904 nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5704086 ...note that the T&CJ had a practice of whiting out some (but not all) advertising signs...it's hard to tell whether that's what they've done with the Christies umbrella sign in this pic... I suspect the Christies sign might in fact prove to be a date marker...my hunch is it was past tense by December 1903/January 1904.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Good thinking! The Christies Umbrella sign shows up in several old photos - that's how I knew what it said.  Of course I can't remember where now ...
